item.title: Japanese players are gobbling up Ghost of Yōtei on PS5, but things look a bit different in the west
item.content:encoded:
October's biggest PlayStation Store downloads.

Sony has whipped up its list of the most downloaded PlayStation Store titles for the month of October, and it turns out Japanese layers are really digging the adventures of Atsu in Ghost of Yōtei. Sucker Punch's epic samurai sequel is top of the PlayStation 5 download list in Japan, but it's relegated to second place in the west, where Battlefield 6 reigns supreme.

Not that Battlefield 6 is slouching in Japan. It manages to secure second place in October, ahead of a top 20 featuring some excellent games. Silent Hill f, for instance, is Japan's seventh most downloaded PS5 title on the PlayStation Store, but is completely missing from the US, Canada, and EU charts. BALL x PIT is also absence in the west, but sits mightily in eighth position over in Japan.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

And of course the west just can't get enough of its balls, with EA Sports FC 26 sitting in third place in the EU (fourth in the US and Canada), and NBA 2K26 taking the third spot outside of the EU. The indomitable GTA 5 clings on tight at four in the EU, meanwhile, and Arc Raiders sweeps fifth place in the west (it's a little lower at nine in Japan). But enough chatter; here's the PS5 list in full.

Japan USA/Canada EU
1 Ghost of Yōtei Battlefield 6 Battlefield 6
2 Battlefield 6 Ghost of Yōtei Ghost of Yōtei
3 Dragon Quest I & II NBA 2K26 EA Sports FC 26
4 Digimon Story: Time Stranger EA Sports FC 26 Grand Theft Auto V
5 Little Nightmares 3 ARC Raiders ARC Raiders
6 Final Fantasy Tactics – Ivalice Chronicles Dispatch Minecraft
7 SILENT HILL f EA SPORTS Madden NFL 26 Jurassic World Evolution 3
8 BALL x PIT Digimon Story Time Stranger UFC 5
9 ARC Raiders Little Nightmares III Little Nightmares III
10 Once Upon a Katamari Damacy Grand Theft Auto V Digimon Story Time Stranger
11 PowerWash Simulator 2 NASCAR 25 Dispatch
12 EA Sports FC 26 Minecraft It Takes Two
13 Minecraft Jurassic World Evolution 3 Dying Light: The Beast
14 NINJA GAIDEN 4 Borderlands 4 Hogwarts Legacy
15 Gran Turismo 7 The Outer Worlds 2 Forza Horizon 5
16 Street Fighter 6 Dying Light: The Beast NBA 2K26
17 Core Keeper Ninja Gaiden 4 Gran Turismo 7
18 Persona 5 The Royal EA SPORTS College Football 26 PowerWash Simulator 2
19 Hogwarts Legacy UFC 5 Hollow Knight: Silksong
20 Monster Hunter Rise NHL 26 Among Us

So there you go! One other thing to note; Dispatch - the new superhero workplace comedy from the former Telltale developers at AdHoc Studio - absolutely smashing it. We knew it had managed to sell 1m copies in just 10 days, but Sony's charts give an even better sense of how well it's doing on the PlayStation Store. It's sitting in 11th place in the EU, but really slugging it out with the big boys in fifth position in the US and Canada. Impressive stuff!

Over on PS4, Red Dead Redemption is leading the charge in the west (versus Code Vein in Japan), and Delta force has Japanese players all aquiver in the free-to-play rankings, compared to Battlefield REDSEC over here. And if you're curious to see the full PS4 and free-to-play rundown, you can check out the western and Japanese lists on the PlayStation Blog.

See 1 more

item.title: Mocked-up images of a new Steam Controller appear, as speculation rises around Valve revealing new gaming hardware this week
item.content:encoded:
A new VR headset? A new gaming console?

We may be about to see a whole new product line of Valve-made gaming hardware. Speculation suggests Valve has a new Steam Controller, virtual reality headset, and console-like device in development, and they may be revealed as soon as this week.

The speculation seems to originate from trusted leaker Brad Lynch (SadlyItsBradley), who stoked the fires overnight by sharing an AI-generated mock-up of what he says the new Steam Controller will look like. Notably, the haptic thumbpads have moved towards the bottom of the controller whereas they used to be towards the top. Lynch claims there's full finger-tracking in the grips, and that the controller can detect how far away your hands are from the handles.

The new Steam Controller will look like this when it launches

Im told that it can also detect how far your hands are from the handles using a simple capsense feature

Similar to the index controllers, but not full finger tracking in the grips pic.twitter.com/loIqpJb0YZ

— Brad Lynch (@SadlyItsBradley) November 9, 2025

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

"Yes. It's an AI slop photo," wrote Lynch on X. "Trained on a real image of the new controller. It was just fast and easy to do it this way. I was not going to post the original one just in case it reveals any sensitive info from the source."

It's also Lynch who suggested a reveal date of 12th November, according to a coherent round-up of Valve hardware rumours on Reddit. As you can see from that post, the bulk of the other patent-related rumours revolve around a new VR headset, which is believed to be codenamed Deckard - although it's also sometimes referred to as Steam Frame. That name - Steam Frame - may also refer to a new operating system developed for the device. The information suggests we're about to see another high-end VR headset priced at around the $1200 mark, possibly more.

The console rumours, meanwhile, revolve around something codenamed Valve Fremont, a games-capable box that features custom AMD processors and a Radeon graphics card. Again, the rumours originate from Brad Lynch, who highlighted the device's appearance on cross-platform benchmarking site Geekbench earlier this year.

Valve has made considerable in-roads into the enthusiast-level games hardware space with the HTC Vive, a VR headset, and the more recent handheld device, Steam Deck. The attraction of a console-like device built to take advantage of Steam's enormous gaming catalogue will be strong indeed. I wonder, if it's true, how much it will cost.
